== Writing tests ==

Write a test like this:

{{{
@RunWith(PowerMockRunner.class)
@PrepareForTest( { YourClassWitEgStaticMethod.class })
public class YourTestCase {
...
}
}}}

Sample code is available in subversion:
 * [http://code.google.com/p/powermock/source/browse/trunk/modules/junit4/src/test/java/org/powermock/modules/junit4/singleton/StupidSingletonTest.java Mocking static methods]
 * [http://code.google.com/p/powermock/source/browse/trunk/modules/junit4/src/test/java/org/powermock/modules/junit4/expectnew/ExpectNewDemoTest.java Expect new instance]
 * [http://code.google.com/p/powermock/source/browse/trunk/modules/junit4/src/test/java/org/powermock/modules/junit4/suppressconstructor/SuppressConstructorDemoTest.java Suppress constructor]

JUnit 3 requires a different setup by creating a suite, since test runners is not available. Please view some examples:
 * [http://code.google.com/p/powermock/source/browse/trunk/modules/junit3/src/test/java/org/powermock/modules/junit3/singleton/StupidSingletonTest.java Mocking static methods with JUnit 3]


== Maven setup ==

 Add the following to your pom.xml:

{{{
<dependency>
	<groupId>org.powermock</groupId>
	<artifactId>powermock-core</artifactId>
	<version>0.5</version>
	<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
	<groupId>org.powermock.modules</groupId>
	<artifactId>powermock-module-junit4</artifactId>
	<version>0.5</version>
	<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
	<groupId>org.easymock</groupId>
	<artifactId>easymockclassextension</artifactId>
	<version>2.2.2</version>
	<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
}}}
